bibl.title: Letter from Bert W. Caldwell to Henry Rose Carter, June 12, 1922

div1.p: Caldwell agrees with Carter that there are no human carriers of yellow fever. He discusses, in detail, his field work in Mexico.

div1.head: Letter from Bert W. Caldwell to Henry Rose Carter, June 12, 1922

Vera Cruz Mexico.
June 12th, 1922.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Your letter of April twenty-fourth was read with
the greatest interest. It cleared up several hazy points
and the facts you present in your letter are most con-
vincing. I could see no substantial reasons for believe-
ing that a reservoir for yellow fever, was maintained by
the existence of so-called “carriers”. The matter had
been suggested and discussed chiefly by my Mexican col-
leagues and your letter convinced them as it did me, of
the distinct improbability of such a factor, as a human
“carrier” of yellow fever, as we understand “carriers”.

The Medical profession in Mexico, more particularly
those interested in Tropical Medicine, hold you in high
esteem. That is rather a rare compliment, for the reason
that they find their Medical dieties more among the French
and German, and occasionally Spanish medical men.

Your theory of the elimination of yellow fever by
failure of the human host has been distinctly supported by
may experiences here in Mexico.

I am returning the Spanish translation on
“Immunity in Yellow Fever”. I have had several typewritten
copies made and handed to the Mexican physicians in this
port. I did this without your permission, but felt that you
would not object.

PODER EJECUTIVO FEDERAL
ESTADOS UNIDOS MEXICANOS

The work in Mexico is rapidly growing to a close.
I feel that intensive ork should be continued in my Zone,
the area of most recent infection until after the present
rainy season or until the first of January at least. There
have been no other cases since the case at the Ingenio San
Cristobal and I anticipate no further difficulties along
the Papapolpoam River. I am, in addition to the regular
brigades working there, sweeping the entire valley with a
Brigada Volante. The second sweep will end about the last
of this month or early in July.

Dr. White who has just left for Tampico with Con-
nor, thinks that there will be no necessity for work after
the rainy season. But I feel that aclose watch should be
maintined until all danger is eliminated, so far as it is
humanly possible to eliminate it.

The possibility of error in diagnosis of the San
Ingenio case is admitted, but it is hardly probable. The
symptoms were classical, both per se and in the sequence of
their development and appearance. Again there were many
others who were living in the Hacienda who exhibited no
symptoms of the disease. The majority of these were immunes.
The patient was a young man from Mexico City who had never
been out of high altitudes except on one short visit to
Tampico. He was in no possible sense immune. He came to
an area of recent known infection by yellow fever and with
-in less than two months was attacked by yellow fever. No
othr cases were reported after his attack, for two reasons.
Intensive anti-stegomyia work was instituted without delay,
and the house in which he was taken ill and the adjoining

houses were s fumigated. The patient him-
self, was isolated under screen, in a two story house, which
contained but a single room in the second story, within
a few hours after he was attacked. I am very much
of the opinion that had not the anti-stegomyia measures
been promptly taken, the patient isolated, and his house
and those adjoining, fumigated, there would have been sev-eral
eral additional cases reported.

We know that we had the infection in San Crist-
obal, and in the city of Cosomolopoam which is but 4 miles
distant aslate as October of 1921, that Teirra Blanca
was infected in November. Tierra Blanca is 30 miles dis-
tant overland. That Ojitlan in Oaxaca was infected badly
in October 1921, and is located on the Papolopoam river
about 65 miles distant. That Cross diedwas infected in Tuxtepec in
Decmeber and Tuxtepec is on the Popolopoam river about
50 miles overland, rather a longer distance by river.

The sugar plantations and sugar mills are
practically continuous, with no great areas intervening
throughout the valley of the Papolopoam, for a distance
of 125 miles along its banks. They Ingenios are within
easy walking distance from each other for the most part.
Large numbers of laborers are imported each year from the
States on the Mexican plateau and they bring with them
their families, wives and children. They move from Ingen
-io to Ingenioa. The movement is comparatively large, and
in normal times has been much larger. In this manner a
constant flow of non-immune material through out this
valley, is maintained for several months of each year
from the first week in January to late in June.

I have observed this area very closely for 18
months past and I am convinced, that the City of Vera
Cruz, has been infected from this area repeatedly and
quite as often as from Merida. There are few phys-
icians in the whole area, with a population of apprximat-
ely 150 000 grouped along its banks, the Papolopoam
has, only two graduate physicians.

No doubt many cases have gone unrecognised, and
a mild epidemic could have occurred in any one of thse
places without being officially recognised, especially
during the revolution, when this fertile valley was the
rendezvous of several large outfits.

It is good of you to remember Mrs. Caldwell
and our boy. You are very close to our affections..
I had to accompany Mrs. Caldwell to the States early
in May. She was in poor health, and she has just left
the Hospital where her pgysicians advise me that her
condition is very satisfactory that there is no occasion
for further anxiety.

I will join her towards the end of this year. I
want very much to complete the present year in Mexico
and at the end of that time return to the States and
take up my work there. I have been kept rather close
in the work here for 18 months and I am ready to retire
when our object is obtained.

I thank you for your kindness in going into
such detailed explanation, and for your cordial expression
for my family.
With every good wish, I remain,
